description.en: Complete guide to Claude Code command line interface, including installation, basic commands, and common workflows

overview.en: Claude Code provides a powerful command-line interface that enables developers to interact with AI directly from their terminal. This guide covers everything from basic installation to advanced usage patterns.

content.en:
## Installation

### Prerequisites
- Node.js 16+ or Python 3.8+
- Terminal access
- Internet connection for initial setup

### Install via npm
```bash
npm install -g @anthropic/claude-code
```

### Install via pip
```bash
pip install claude-code
```

### Verify Installation
```bash
claude --version
claude --help
```

content.en:
## Core Commands

### Start Interactive Session
```bash
claude
```
Starts an interactive coding session where you can chat with Claude and get real-time help.

### Quick Code Generation
```bash
claude "Create a React component for user profile"
```

### File Operations
```bash
# Analyze existing file
claude --file src/components/User.js "Optimize this component"

# Generate new file
claude --output src/utils/helpers.js "Create utility functions for data validation"
```

### Project Analysis
```bash
# Analyze entire project
claude --analyze

# Analyze specific directory
claude --analyze src/
```

codeExamples.title: Basic Session Workflow
codeExamples.code:
# Start Claude Code
claude

# In the interactive session:
> Create a function to validate email addresses
> Add error handling to the login function
> Refactor this component to use hooks

# Exit session
> /exit

codeExamples.title: Batch Processing
codeExamples.code:
# Process multiple files
claude --batch src/**/*.js "Add JSDoc comments to all functions"

# Generate documentation
claude --docs --output README.md "Create comprehensive project documentation"

bestPractices.title: Use Clear, Specific Prompts
bestPractices.description: Be specific about what you want. Instead of 'fix this code', say 'optimize this function for better performance and add error handling'.

bestPractices.title: Break Down Complex Tasks
bestPractices.description: For large refactoring or feature implementation, break the task into smaller, manageable pieces.

bestPractices.title: Review Generated Code
bestPractices.description: Always review and test the generated code before committing to ensure it meets your requirements and coding standards.

commonIssues.solution: Ensure Claude Code is properly installed and your PATH is updated. Try reinstalling or check your shell configuration.
This usually indicates network issues. Check your internet connection and try restarting the session.

source.author: Anthropic Documentation Team

description.en: Advanced patterns and workflows for integrating Claude Code into complex development environments and CI/CD pipelines

overview.en: Learn advanced techniques for integrating Claude Code into sophisticated development workflows, including automated testing, continuous integration, and team collaboration patterns.

content.en:
## GitHub Actions Integration

### Automated Code Review
```yaml
name: Claude Code Review
on:
  pull_request:
    types: [opened, synchronize]

jobs:
  claude-review:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3
      - name: Setup Claude Code
        run: npm install -g @anthropic/claude-code
      - name: Review PR
        run: |
          claude --review --pr ${{ github.event.number }} \
            --focus security,performance,best-practices
```

### Automated Documentation
```yaml
- name: Generate Documentation
  run: |
    claude --docs --auto-update \
      --output docs/ \
      --format markdown
```

description.en: Comprehensive guide to the most popular Claude Code subagents collection featuring 74 specialized AI agents for automatic task delegation and cost optimization

overview.en: The wshobson/agents repository represents the most comprehensive and production-ready collection of Claude Code subagents available. With 74 specialized agents covering everything from frontend development to AI engineering, this collection demonstrates best practices for automatic context detection, intelligent task routing, and cost-optimized model selection.

content.en:

The agents collection follows a clean, standardized structure:


### âš™ï¸ **Platform & Tools** (4 agents)
- Context Management & Optimization
- Documentation Generation
- Code Quality & Review
- Performance Optimization

content.en:
## Installation Methods

### Method 1: Standard User-Level Installation
```bash
# Navigate to Claude Code config directory
cd ~/.claude

# Clone the agents repository
git clone https://github.com/wshobson/agents.git

# Verify installation
ls agents/
```

### Method 2: Project-Level Installation
```bash
# In your project root
mkdir -p .claude/agents
cd .claude/agents

# Clone specific agents or entire collection
git clone https://github.com/wshobson/agents.git wh-bundle
```

### Method 3: Selective Installation
```bash
# Install only specific agents
curl -O https://raw.githubusercontent.com/wshobson/agents/main/frontend-developer.md
curl -O https://raw.githubusercontent.com/wshobson/agents/main/backend-architect.md
```

## Verification & Testing

### Check Agent Recognition
```bash
# Start Claude Code and test agent activation
claude

# In Claude Code session, try triggering agents:
> Create a React component for user authentication
> Design a REST API for user management
> Optimize this database query for performance
```

### Configuration Priority
Claude Code follows this priority order:
1. **Project-level**: `.claude/agents/` (highest priority)
2. **User-level**: `~/.claude/agents/`
3. **Global**: System-wide installations

**Note**: Project-level agents override user-level agents with the same name.

content.en:
## Standard Agent Configuration

Each agent follows a standardized YAML frontmatter structure:

```yaml
---
name: agent-identifier
description: Clear description of when this agent should be invoked
model: haiku|sonnet|opus  # Optional - cost optimization
tools: tool1, tool2       # Optional - defaults to all tools
category: domain          # Optional - organization
---
System prompt defining the agent's specialized role and capabilities
```

## Configuration Parameters

### Required Fields
- **name**: Unique identifier (kebab-case recommended)
- **description**: Triggers for automatic agent selection

### Optional Fields
- **model**: Cost optimization (haiku < sonnet < opus)
- **tools**: Restrict tool access for security/performance
- **category**: Organizational grouping

## Model Selection Strategy

### Cost-Effective Task Delegation
```yaml
# Low Complexity - Haiku Model
model: haiku
use_cases:
  - Basic data analysis
  - Documentation generation
  - Standard responses
  - Simple code reviews

# Medium Complexity - Sonnet Model  
model: sonnet
use_cases:
  - Development tasks
  - Code generation
  - Testing workflows
  - API design

# High Complexity - Opus Model
model: opus
use_cases:
  - Security auditing
  - Architecture review
  - AI/ML engineering
  - Complex system design
```

## Tool Access Management

### Restricted Tool Access
```yaml
# Security-focused agent with limited tools
tools: search, read
# Prevents file modification for security analysis

# Development agent with full access
tools: filesystem, search, web, terminal
# Full development capabilities
```

### Default Tool Behavior
```yaml
# When tools not specified, agent gets:
- filesystem: Read/write file operations
- search: Code and documentation search
- web: Internet access for research
- terminal: Command execution (when safe)
```

content.en:
## Top 10 Most Used Agents

### ğŸ¯ 1. Frontend Developer
**Triggers**: React, Vue, Angular, component, responsive, UI
**Model**: Sonnet (medium complexity)
**Use Cases**:
- React component architecture
- Responsive design implementation
- State management (Redux, Zustand)
- CSS frameworks integration

### ğŸ—ï¸ 2. Backend Architect  
**Triggers**: API, database, server, microservices, architecture
**Model**: Sonnet/Opus (complexity-dependent)
**Use Cases**:
- RESTful API design
- Database schema optimization
- Microservices architecture
- Performance optimization

### ğŸ¤– 3. AI Engineer
**Triggers**: LLM, machine learning, AI, neural network, model
**Model**: Opus (high complexity)
**Use Cases**:
- LLM integration (OpenAI, Anthropic)
- RAG systems with vector databases
- Model fine-tuning and deployment
- AI application architecture

### ğŸ¨ 4. UI/UX Designer
**Triggers**: design system, accessibility, user experience, wireframe
**Model**: Sonnet
**Use Cases**:
- Design system creation
- Accessibility compliance (WCAG)
- User flow optimization
- Design token management

### ğŸ”’ 5. Security Expert
**Triggers**: security, vulnerability, penetration testing, audit
**Model**: Opus (critical analysis)
**Use Cases**:
- Security vulnerability assessment
- Penetration testing strategies
- Secure coding practices
- Compliance requirements (SOC2, GDPR)

### ğŸ“± 6. Mobile Developer
**Triggers**: mobile, React Native, Flutter, iOS, Android
**Model**: Sonnet
**Use Cases**:
- Cross-platform mobile development
- Native performance optimization
- App store deployment
- Platform-specific features

### âš¡ 7. Performance Engineer
**Triggers**: performance, optimization, bottleneck, scaling
**Model**: Sonnet/Opus
**Use Cases**:
- Application performance profiling
- Database query optimization
- Caching strategies
- Load testing and monitoring

### ğŸ”§ 8. DevOps Engineer
**Triggers**: CI/CD, Docker, Kubernetes, deployment, infrastructure
**Model**: Sonnet
**Use Cases**:
- CI/CD pipeline optimization
- Container orchestration
- Infrastructure as Code
- Monitoring and alerting

### ğŸ“Š 9. Data Engineer
**Triggers**: data pipeline, ETL, analytics, BigQuery, warehouse
**Model**: Sonnet
**Use Cases**:
- Data pipeline architecture
- ETL process optimization
- Data warehouse design
- Real-time analytics

### âš™ï¸ 10. Context Manager
**Triggers**: context, optimization, memory, token efficiency
**Model**: Haiku (efficiency focused)
**Use Cases**:
- Context window optimization
- Information prioritization
- Token usage reduction
- Session management

content.en:
## How Claude Code Selects Agents

Claude Code uses sophisticated context analysis to automatically select the most appropriate agent:

### 1. Keyword Analysis (30% weight)
```yaml
frontend-developer:
  triggers: ["React", "component", "CSS", "responsive", "UI"]
  
backend-architect:
  triggers: ["API", "database", "server", "microservices"]
  
security-expert:
  triggers: ["security", "vulnerability", "audit", "penetration"]
```

### 2. File Type Detection (25% weight)
```yaml
file_patterns:
  frontend:
    - "*.jsx", "*.tsx", "*.vue", "*.css", "*.scss"
  backend:
    - "*.js", "*.ts", "*.py", "*.go", "*.java"
  mobile:
    - "**/ios/**", "**/android/**", "*.swift", "*.kt"
  infrastructure:
    - "Dockerfile", "*.yaml", "*.tf", "*.yml"
```

### 3. Project Structure Analysis (20% weight)
```yaml
project_indicators:
  react_app:
    - "package.json" with "react" dependency
    - "src/components/" directory
    - ".tsx" or ".jsx" files
    
  api_service:
    - "app.py", "server.js", "main.go"
    - "routes/" or "endpoints/" directory
    - Database configuration files
    
  mobile_app:
    - "ios/", "android/" directories
    - "pubspec.yaml" (Flutter)
    - "package.json" with React Native
```

### 4. Task Classification (15% weight)
```yaml
task_types:
  development:
    verbs: ["create", "build", "implement", "develop"]
    
  debugging:
    verbs: ["fix", "debug", "troubleshoot", "resolve"]
    
  optimization:
    verbs: ["optimize", "improve", "enhance", "refactor"]
    
  analysis:
    verbs: ["analyze", "review", "audit", "assess"]
```

### 5. Context History (10% weight)
Claude Code remembers recent interactions and maintains context continuity:

```yaml
context_memory:
  recent_agents: ["frontend-developer", "ui-ux-designer"]
  active_project_type: "react-application"
  user_preferences: 
    - prefers_typescript: true
    - uses_tailwind: true
    - testing_framework: "jest"
```

## Multi-Agent Orchestration

### Parallel Agent Execution
```bash
# User request: "Create a full-stack user authentication system"

# Claude Code automatically delegates to:
1. backend-architect     â†’ API design & database schema
2. security-expert       â†’ Security best practices
3. frontend-developer    â†’ Login/signup components
4. ui-ux-designer       â†’ User experience flow
5. devops-engineer      â†’ Deployment configuration
```

### Sequential Agent Workflows
```bash
# User request: "Optimize this slow application"

# Sequential workflow:
1. performance-engineer  â†’ Identify bottlenecks
2. backend-architect     â†’ Database optimization
3. frontend-developer    â†’ Client-side optimization
4. devops-engineer      â†’ Infrastructure scaling
```

codeExamples.title: AI Engineer Agent Configuration
codeExamples.code:
---
name: ai-engineer
description: AI engineer specializing in LLM applications and generative AI systems
model: opus
tools: filesystem, search, web
category: ai-ml
---

You are an AI engineer specializing in:

ğŸ¤– **LLM Integration & Development**
- OpenAI GPT, Anthropic Claude, Google PaLM APIs
- Hugging Face transformers and model deployment
- Custom fine-tuning and prompt engineering
- Cost optimization and rate limiting strategies

ğŸ—„ï¸ **RAG & Vector Systems**
- Vector databases (Qdrant, Pinecone, Weaviate, Chroma)
- Embedding strategies and similarity search
- Chunk optimization and retrieval enhancement
- Hybrid search implementations

ğŸ—ï¸ **AI Application Architecture**
- Microservices for AI workloads
- Scalable inference pipelines
- Model versioning and A/B testing
- Monitoring and observability for AI systems

Focus on production-ready solutions with reliability and cost efficiency.

codeExamples.title: Frontend Developer Agent Configuration
codeExamples.code:
---
name: frontend-developer
description: Build React components, implement responsive layouts, handle client-side state management
model: sonnet
tools: filesystem, search
category: development
---

You are a frontend development expert specializing in:

âš›ï¸ **React Ecosystem**
- Component architecture and composition patterns
- Hooks and state management (Redux, Zustand, Context)
- Performance optimization (React.memo, useMemo, lazy loading)
- Testing with Jest and React Testing Library

ğŸ¨ **Modern CSS & Styling**
- CSS-in-JS solutions (styled-components, emotion)
- Utility frameworks (Tailwind CSS, ChakraUI)
- Responsive design and mobile-first approach
- CSS Grid and Flexbox mastery

âš¡ **Performance & UX**
- Core Web Vitals optimization
- Progressive Web App features
- Accessibility compliance (WCAG guidelines)
- Bundle optimization and code splitting

Deliver production-ready components with excellent user experience.

codeExamples.title: Context Manager Agent Configuration
codeExamples.code:
---
name: context-manager
description: Optimize context usage, manage information flow, and improve token efficiency
model: haiku
tools: search, filesystem
category: optimization
---

You specialize in context optimization and efficient information management:

ğŸ§  **Context Window Optimization**
- Intelligent information prioritization
- Relevant content extraction and summarization
- Token usage reduction strategies
- Context boundary management

ğŸ“Š **Information Architecture**
- Hierarchical information structuring
- Key-value extraction from large contexts
- Cross-reference optimization
- Memory-efficient data organization

âš¡ **Performance Strategies**
- Lazy loading of context information
- Incremental context building
- Smart caching mechanisms
- Real-time context relevance scoring

Focus on maximizing information density while minimizing token consumption.

bestPractices.title: Use Descriptive Agent Names
bestPractices.description: Choose clear, descriptive names that make it obvious when the agent should be triggered. Use kebab-case for consistency.

bestPractices.title: Optimize Model Selection
bestPractices.description: Match model complexity to task requirements. Use Haiku for simple tasks, Sonnet for development work, and Opus for complex analysis.

bestPractices.title: Implement Proper Tool Restrictions
bestPractices.description: Limit tool access based on agent purpose. Security agents should have read-only access, while development agents need full filesystem access.

bestPractices.title: Create Comprehensive Trigger Descriptions
bestPractices.description: Write detailed descriptions that help Claude Code understand exactly when to activate each agent. Include keywords, contexts, and use cases.

bestPractices.title: Test Agent Activation
bestPractices.description: Regularly test your agents with different prompts to ensure they're being triggered correctly and producing expected results.

bestPractices.title: Organize by Project Needs
bestPractices.description: Use project-level agent installations to customize behavior for specific projects while maintaining user-level defaults.

commonIssues.solution: Check the agent's description field for relevant keywords. Ensure the description clearly indicates when the agent should be used. Try using more specific trigger terms in your prompts.
Review agent descriptions for overlap. Make sure each agent has unique, specific trigger conditions. Consider renaming agents or refining their descriptions.

commonIssues.issue: High costs with Opus model agents
commonIssues.solution: Evaluate if tasks really need Opus complexity. Many development tasks work well with Sonnet. Reserve Opus for security audits, architecture reviews, and AI/ML work.

commonIssues.issue: Agent conflicts between user and project levels
commonIssues.solution: Remember that project-level agents override user-level ones. Use unique names or deliberately override with project-specific versions.

description.en: Essential Claude Code functionality and basic usage
Advanced workflows, automation, and integration patterns
Custom AI agents and specialized sub-agents

metadata.description: Enhanced Claude Code documentation collection with full content support
